1123093928553541632.text: Just confirmed that the MG2040 and the ESD7008 are the same device sold under two different datasheets. The "NC" pins of the ESD7007 are really the common GND of the MG2040 and measure as such. The pentagonal pads of the MG2040 are a lie, they're both square. Lol @onsemi.pic.twitter.com/U4UsDunXZJ

1123456583697162243.text:
Oh look, Bloomberg @business is spewing bullshit again. And immediately being called out on it by @vodafone

I think we can solidly file Bloomberg as an unreliable tabloid now, at least regarding infosec.pic.twitter.com/0BNegMOmoF

1117125972254269440.text:
What happens when you short out the level shifters on Glasgow with the protection resistors bypassed?

I guess we'll find out tomorrow morning. Each of the poor things is dissipating about 1W.pic.twitter.com/QhzCPApYJN

1115147850604658688.text: Tweaked a few pixels to make it compress even worse. Can't say I understand exactly what's going on here; I did start from a basic premise of "doing crap on the luma channel on a 1x1 grid, on the chroma channel on a 2x2 grid" but after that it was just poking random pixels.pic.twitter.com/FoB3lQR58X

1121807450737242117.text: Saturday (2019-04-27) at 14:00 JST it is then, like last time. 05:00 UTC / 07:00 CEST / 22:00 PDT (Friday) / 01:00 EDT. Probably won't be as long as last time, though.https://twitter.com/marcan42/status/1120652051623497728 …

1117689883600965632.text: Interestingly, the new revC1 part (which has been retrofitted to this revC0 unit to the left, on the B side) does not have this problem, at least at whatever level the I/Os naturally float to when disconnected and powered at 3.3V.

1123094022203985920.text: Update: confirmed, it's true. They really are identical.https://twitter.com/marcan42/status/1123093928553541632 …

1117689527110262784.text: Here's a fun one. The old GPIO expander that we had in revC0 for pull-up control gets slightly warm when not doing anything. Ground all the I/Os and it immediately cools down. Looks like those input buffers have high leakage when the input is floating!pic.twitter.com/fGxdlvlqCX

1120652051623497728.text: Another stream coming up: reverse engineering the proprietary USB audio interface that is part of this DJ controller (that @_klange graciously loaned me) and adding support to Linux. Thinking of doing it this weekend. Anyone interested?pic.twitter.com/OFAhzVigML

1121340011339603968.text: When your voltage regulator accidentally has one bit of surprisingly non-volatile memory. Turns out Glasgow revC0 can lock up in an interesting way when you short out the Vio output rail on a port. This was fun to work out last night.https://github.com/GlasgowEmbedded/Glasgow/issues/135 …

1122181926561779717.text: Apparently someone from @BYU is sending completely blank e-mails (no data at all) to random postmaster accounts? https://imaal.byu.edu/  talks about DNS queries, but these are Actual Emails that reach the inboxes of Real Humans. @CaseyDeccio, this is not okay.pic.twitter.com/fdbg5ETA1x

1123457491470311425.text: Yeah, no shit. We know @Huawei are incompetent and have a million vulnerabilities and probably suck at fixing them. That doesn't make them "backdoors".pic.twitter.com/Uce16vSxsk

1117681305469087745.text: Conclusion: after 20 hours or so of torture, both pins appear to function normally. Input leakage identical to the rest, output performance at 24MHz identical to the rest (measured with a scope), and they work fine in a basic JTAG test at 3.3V.
